bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Dmitry Ryvkin is an assistant professor of economics at Florida State University where he teaches upper division undergraduate and graduate courses in microeconomic theory and econometrics. He has published articles in multiple journals including Management Science, Games and Economic Behavior and Journal of Economic Behavior and Organization. Dr. Ryvkin received a Bachelor and Master of Science degrees in Physics from the Ural State University (Ekaterinburg, Russia), a PhD in Physics from Michigan State University, and a Master of Arts and PhD degrees in Economics from the Center for Economic Research and Graduate Education (Prague, the Czech Republic).

abstract.p: Doping, or the use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs, is an epidemic problem in sports ranging from the Olympics to high school athletics. This article presents a theoretical model of doping use in a contest environment. The authors show that, under fairly general conditions, the minimal frequency of random testing to prevent doping use increases in the number of contestants. The presence of even a small penalty, in addition to expulsion from the contest, makes random testing more effective, especially in large contests. For a given testing frequency, the minimal penalty to prevent doping can be nonmonotonic in the number of contestants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In tournaments, a number of participants (players) compete for a valuable prize. Examples include rent-seeking contests (Congleton, Hillman, & Konrad, 2008; Corchón, 2007; Lockard & Tullock, 2001), R&D competition (Taylor, 1995), relative performance-based contracts and promotion in firms (Lazear & Rosen, 1981; Rosen, 1986), and sports (Szymanski, 2003). Incentives in tournaments are often provided in a “winner-take-all” manner, that is, only one participant is substantially rewarded for her effort (e.g., receives a promotion, or wins a gold medal), while others waste their resources.

Winner-take-all environments with high stakes are notorious for their ability to create undesirable side incentives leading to destructive actions, such as sabotage by employees (Carpenter, Matthews, & Schirm, 2010; Harbring & Irlenbusch, 2008; Konrad, 2000; Münster, 2006a), cheating by managers (Evans, Gilpatric, McKee, & Vossler, 2008), and doping by athletes (Dilger, Frick, & Tolsdorf, 2007).

In this article, we consider a winner-take-all contest prior to which players can engage in an illegal activity, henceforth referred to as “doping,” that increases their productivity. Although most of the examples, terminology and intuition here draw upon the realm of illegal performance-enhancing drugs use in sports, our results are also applicable to other environments where “cheating” can increase one’s chances of securing a valuable prize in a competitive setting. Examples include bribing government officials in public procurement, forging data in research, or covering up information on potential risks in investment banking.

Dilger et al. (2007) provide an excellent review of the literature on doping in sports. Most studies of doping use view it as a socially undesirable activity 1 and discuss, theoretically and empirically, the effectiveness of various antidoping policies. Without regulation, the problem of doping use is essentially a prisoner’s dilemma, with the noncooperative equilibrium outcome being that all players are doped. Anecdotal evidence from the early days when performance-enhancing drugs were not explicitly banned, suggests that this equilibrium prediction is a reasonable approximation of reality at least in some sports, such as cycling and track and field (Dilger et al., 2007; see also Petróczi, 2007 for a recent study on athletes' attitudes to doping). A number of antidoping regulation mechanisms aiming at creating the incentives to support the socially desirable outcome of no doping have been discussed in the literature. Haugen (2004) and Eber and Thépot (1999) consider a simple institution with random testing and penalties. Breivik (1992) and Eber (2008) show that certain types of athletes' social preferences (such as other-regarding preferences over payoffs or “fair play”) may lead to self-sustained no-doping equilibria. Berentsen (2002) proposes only testing winners after the competition. Bird and Wagner (1997) discuss drug diaries and peer monitoring as an alternative method. These articles use stylized models of competition, typically involving two players in a
2 × 2
normal form game with doping use as a dichotomous choice. The setting allows them to capture basic properties of antidoping policies, such as the fact that more frequent monitoring, or more severe penalty, or lower value of the prize, or lower doping efficiency, or higher health costs of doping, tend to decrease doping use. Additionally, it allows for welfare comparison of different antidoping policies (Berentsen, 2002; Eber & Thépot, 1999). However, the strategic interaction between effort and doping use is missing in this type of analysis.

In contrast to the earlier articles, and similarly to this article, Konrad (2005), Kräkel (2007), Curry and Mongrain (2009), Gilpatric (2011), and Stowe and Gilpatric (2010) are the examples of recent studies that analyze the doping problem using a tournament model with players choosing both effort and doping levels. Konrad (2005) treats doping as a context-free continuous second input and compares the situation when it is “illegal” (i.e., the only allowed choice of the second input is zero) to “legalization” when players are free to choose arbitrary amounts of both inputs, and shows that legalization is always welfare-enhancing. However, Konrad (2005) does not consider any incentive-compatible doping prevention mechanisms.

Curry and Mongrain (2009) look at the role of the prize structure and differential monitoring in doping deterrence costs. They find that the presence of the second prize and monitoring the winner more frequently than the loser reduces monitoring costs under fairly general conditions. In their model, Curry and Mongrain (2009) use a general contest success function but limit consideration to two-player contests.

Gilpatric (2011) uses a Lazear and Rosen (1981) style tournament model with doping as a continuous variable added to a player’s effort. In addition to the standard independent random monitoring of players, Gilpatric (2011) studies “correlated audits” under which with some probability all players are inspected at once, or none at all. He shows that correlated audits lead to less cheating than uncorrelated audits if the detection technology is sufficiently effective. Gilpatric (2011) also shows that, in two-player contests, awarding the winner’s prize to the loser if the winner is found cheating reduces the equilibrium level of cheating. 2 Additionally, Gilpatric (2011) considers contests of more than two players and finds that, somewhat counterintuitively, the equilibrium level of cheating may increase in the number of players under some conditions.

Kräkel (2007) studies doping in two-player Lazear and Rosen (1981) type contests of heterogeneous players. He shows that the decision on whether or not to use doping is determined by three factors: the “likelihood effect” (the extent to which doping increases one’s probability of winning), the “cost effect” (the effect of doping on effort costs), and the “base-salary effect” (a reduction in the expected base salary due to the possibility of being caught doped). Additionally, Kräkel (2007) compares the total effort exerted in the contest in the cases of ex ante (before the tournament) and ex post (after the tournament) testing and finds that ex ante testing leads to higher total effort.

Similar to Kräkel (2007), Stowe and Gilpatric (2010) also analyze the case of heterogeneous players, but focus on the impact of testing probability, correlated audits and differential testing. They find that for relatively low testing probabilities, the favorite is more likely to cheat than the underdog, but the result is reversed for sufficiently high testing probabilities. Stowe and Gilpatric (2010) also demonstrate, similar to Gilpatric (2011), the advantages of correlated audits and differential monitoring.

In the present article, we analyze the problem of doping in a contest environment with an arbitrary number of contestants. We augment the baseline contest model by a simple antidoping institution that involves random independent monitoring (testing) of players after they make a decision whether or not to use doping, but before the contest takes place. 3 The players that are caught doped are not allowed to participate in the contest and incur a penalty. There are several important differences between our model and the existing models. First, for a large part of the analysis we use general reduced-form payoff functions for the contest stage. This makes our model applicable not only to contests but to arbitrary competitive mechanisms, such as auctions or oligopolistic competition. We then develop an application of the general model to a Tullock (1980) type contest, whereas most other studies use a Lazear and Rosen (1981) type model. Second, although players in our model are symmetric ex ante, they are asymmetric ex post because effort choice takes place after the decision on doping use, and users and nonusers choose different effort levels. Finally, we focus on the impact of the number of players on doping prevention. 4

In our model, due to the possibility of elimination of violators, the number of players at the contest stage is uncertain and endogenously determined in equilibrium. Contests with an uncertain but exogenous number of players have been studied by Myerson and Wärneryd (2006) and Münster (2006b). Higgins, Shughart, and Tollison (1985) discussed simple contests with free entry. Schoonbeek (2009) considered a contest where one player may or may not enter depending on the amount of the bribe she gets from other participants. Related to this is also the literature on auctions with endogenous entry, for example, Levin and Smith (1994), Chakraborty and Kosmopoulou (2001), Bajari and Hortacsu (2003), Pevnistkaya (2004), Ivanova-Stenzel and Salmon (2008), Palfrey and Pevnitskaya (2008). The new and important feature of our setting, as compared to the settings discussed in these articles, is that, by choosing whether or not to use doping, the players affect not only their entry probability but also their productivity (or, in equivalent alternative formulations, their ability or prize valuation). Thus, we describe a mechanism with endogenous entry and endogenous heterogeneity of players.

Our results can be divided into two groups. The first set of results deals with equilibrium existence and properties under a general model of the final stage game. We identify the properties of the reduced-form payoffs of the final stage game that guarantee the existence and uniqueness of a “natural” equilibrium, whose basic properties are similar to those identified in prior studies. Specifically, as expected, the equilibrium probability of doping use decreases in the probability of testing and the size of the penalty. We also show how the minimal enforcement parameters, testing probability and penalty size, required to sustain the no-doping equilibrium change with the number of players and find some counterintuitive nonmonotonicities. This result is consistent with Gilpatric (2011) who showed that the level of cheating may increase with the number of players. The second set of results arises from the application of the general model to a Tullock (1980) type contest. We identify a crucial role the penalty plays in doping prevention. Without penalty, nearly all players would have to be tested to guarantee the no-doping equilibrium in large tournaments, whereas in the presence of a positive penalty the minimal testing probability is nonmonotonic and ultimately decreases in the number of players.

The rest of the article is organized as follows. In The Model and Main Results section, we present a general framework and formulate our main results. The analysis in this section is largely model-independent, in the sense that it treats the final stage contest as an abstract game with known equilibrium payoff functions. To further explore the properties of the equilibrium, in the section An Application to a Tullock Contest, we impose a parametric structure on the final stage contest game using a prominent contest model and provide a numerical illustration of the results. The Discussion and Conclusion section follows.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we develop a game-theoretic model of doping use, or, more generally, cheating, in symmetric winner-take-all competitive environments with an arbitrary number of contestants. Without an appropriately designed prevention mechanism, such environments strongly encourage doping or cheating as a dominant strategy. We, therefore, augment the contest environment with a simple testing/expulsion/penalty doping prevention mechanism and identify its properties. We show that, unsurprisingly, the equilibrium probability of doping use decreases in the probability of testing and the size of the penalty. These findings are in line with other studies, for example, Berentsen (2002) and Stowe and Gilpatric (2010). As the probability of testing and the size of the penalty are, to a certain extent, substitutes in terms of antidoping enforcement, it is of interest to study the properties of the penalty-testing “frontier” as the locus of doping prevention policies.

We found that the penalty-testing frontier exhibits interesting nonmonotonicities. For a given probability of testing, the minimal penalty necessary to ensure no doping use in equilibrium can be nonmonotonic as a function of the number of players. When there are many potential participants in the contest, each player’s chances of winning and expected payoff become very small, and hence the incentives to use doping decrease. However, for a moderate number of participants, the expected gain from using doping can be greater than the loss from adding more players to the contest, and the incentives to use doping can increase with the number of potential participants. Similarly, we found that for a given size of the penalty, the minimal testing probability that ensures no doping use in equilibrium can be nonmonotonic as a function of the number of players. These nonmonotonicities are related to the result of Gilpatric (2011) who found, albeit in a different model, that the equilibrium level of cheating can be nonmonotonic in the number of contest participants.

One of the major results of our analysis is that a monetary penalty, in addition to disqualification, plays a crucial role in doping prevention. We predict that the introduction of such a penalty will lead to a drastic reduction in the costs of monitoring necessary to prevent doping. However, to impose and enforce such a penalty in sports may be problematic from a legal perspective.

Indeed, one can argue that by sufficiently increasing the penalty it is possible to reduce the costs of testing virtually to zero and thus easily solve the doping problem. However, doping with most substances used today is not a violation from the viewpoint of “general law,” 13 that is, it can only be subject to a penalty within a sport organization, such as the International Olympic Committee, or a national sport association. The severity of such penalties is very limited, and it is unclear to what extent they can be legally applied to individual athletes. Moreover, penalties have to be substantial because the relevant scale for a meaningful penalty is the value of the winner’s prize to the athlete. As long as the size of the penalty remains negligible compared to the value of the prize, the threat of the penalty will play little to no role in decision making. Given that most athletes are prepared to literally sacrifice their life for a gold medal (Andrews, 1998), a commensurate penalty may not be feasible. An indirect measure of the value of winning to athletes is the expected lifelong stream of payments resulting from it. Champions' endorsements can range up to tens of millions of dollars per year (Fort, 2006, p. 210). The same is true regarding the bonuses of CEOs in investment banking. However, while the latter can go to jail for fraud, the former can typically do away with relatively small contractual penalties. 14

Given the difficulty with devising a significant penalty in sports, the remaining available mechanism of doping deterrence is to exclude violators from competition. This makes the minimal testing probability necessary to ensure no doping in equilibrium without penalty an important object for analysis. We have shown that, under fairly general conditions, this testing probability is an increasing function of the effectiveness of doping and the number of players. Thus, more frequent testing is needed as the number of potential participants increases. Testing costs, therefore, will rise faster than the number of participants. This result implies that it makes sense to split competition into smaller sub-contests with separate prizes whenever possible.

Outside of sports, significant penalties are feasible. As we show, the presence of even a relatively small penalty (in our numerical example, 1% of the value of the prize) changes the dependence of the minimal testing probability on the number of players from monotonically increasing to nonmonotonic. Thus, organizers are advised to use penalty in addition to expulsion as a cheating prevention mechanism in large groups. Even in sports, a nominal penalty (in terms of the value of the prize) can significantly reduce the incentives to dope compared to the no-penalty case.

Our model abstracts from personal negative consequences of doping for users, such as possible health and moral costs in sports and other environments. However, the presence of such consequences can only decrease the severity of the doping use problem, therefore our results describe the “worst case scenario” in this regard.

The analysis can be extended in a number of ways. It can be of interest to explore the effect of players' ex ante heterogeneity on doping use. Heterogeneity in abilities is, obviously, an important part of contest environments in applications, and new types of results, such as cutoff equilibria where only players with abilities above certain level use or do not use doping, are expected. Other possible directions include analyzing the role of risk attitudes and more complex antidoping institutions.

Some studies consider doping in a more general context of competition with multiple inputs (Konrad, 2005; see also Epstein & Hefeker 2003). These articles adopt a more neutral view of doping as one of the inputs, not necessarily illegal or undesirable, and show that, generally, the presence of such an input increases social welfare.
Curry and Mongrain (2009) obtain a similar result in their model by showing that the monitoring probability necessary to deter cheating in equilibrium is lower in the presence of such re-awarding.

Independent random testing (also termed “uncorrelated audit” by Gilpatric, 2011) prior to competition is the most basic antidoping institution discussed in the literature. Berentsen (2002) found that testing winners after the tournament is more effective. Stowe and Gilpatric (2010) and Curry and Mongrain (2009) show that correlated testing and ability-dependent differential testing may also be superior alternatives. In practice, all top athletes can be tested periodically, whether they participate in a tournament at any given point in time or not, and winners are tested more frequently (always, in some cases). Thus, testing may occur before, during, or after a tournament, and is differential. In the present article, we analyze the most basic institution and focus on the effect of the number of contestants on decisions. The question to what extent the results of this article hold under alternative antidoping institutions is left for future research.

Gilpatric (2011) is the only other article that models doping use in a contest of more than two players. However, effort and doping are chosen simultaneously and symmetrically in his model, and thus there is no heterogeneity at the contest stage.

Thus, doping is modeled as a dichotomous choice, which is similar to the earlier articles (e.g., Berentsen, 2002) and also to Curry and Mongrain (2009) and Stowe and Gilpatric (2010), but different from Gilpatric (2011).

Interestingly, some sport associations have recently realized that it makes sense to impose monetary penalties on athletes and coaches beyond the one- or two-year disqualification for doping. For example, the “Zero-Tolerance Action Plan” of the USA Track & Field (USATF) contains a proposal to “Impose fines against athletes found guilty. In addition to any warnings or suspensions imposed by USATF and IAAF rules, USATF will launch a program to fine guilty athletes. Those convicted of stimulant positives will be fined up to $10,000. Those convicted of offenses involving a 2-year ban (including, e.g., steroids or amphetamines) will be fined up to $100,000. All fines collected will be used for antidoping research, education, and investigation.” See http://www.usatf.org/about/legal/antidoping/ZeroTolerance_actionPlan.asp for further details. At the same time, some associations, e.g., the US Tennis Association (USTA), continue to only use disqualification (see http://www.usta.com/Archive/News/Community-Tennis/Community-News/13942_United_States_Tennis_Association_AntiDoping_Program/ ).
